First impressions, ok to be completely honest I only originally checked out this show because it had a trap it in and I liked all the memes that where coming from this series was what originally got my interest, but of course once I started watching it there was a lot more than to the series than I first thought.
(Also quick Side note i will be covering both seasons of the anime in this review)
Story, 6/10 
So in today's modern anime where half the series that are coming out are about ether about high schools or cute girls doing cutethings how dose a series My Teen Romantic Comedy SNAFU stand out in a market which at this point has already reached peak inflation, besides being about a bitter, anti-social teenager named  Hachiman forced into a school club called service club, the  that help people fix their problems, totally haven't  heard about this before a seruies about a high school student being  forced into an excuse  for plot club  with cute girls and sarcasm aside.

The story is basically the three of them trying to fix poor, poor Japanese high school students problems and there some sort of love triangle forming because light novel. which at first thought I figured this is just going to be another generic school romantic comedy that I would forget in a week, and considering  my experience with the medium you can't exactly blame me for having that viewpoint.

But i was very surprised in how even though this series is mostly about  high school bullshit, i did find it interesting that this series actually talks  and criticiszes human  society. Well to be more specific it's more aless  socal commenty  and the problems that can arise  which i find very interesting and the fact this series trys to more thought provoking than your average romantic school comady with teenagers is really impressive to say the least.

The ideas of don't always go with the crowd, be yourself and some people are going to be two-faced assholes.  the fact it doesn't devolve into otaku culture to get it point across just adds weight to the commentary because whoever wrote this dose has this understanding  of how people tick and doesn't use it for an excuse for edgelord bullshit, but more a less is telling you this is normal human behaviour and it isn't perfect, but that's fine because even if problems do come up there are ways to fix them to get around them. 


But the major prolem is even though it's a lot more thought provoking and actually trys to be interesting with its messages and etc,  it is sadly constrained by the fact that at the end of the day it is still a teen romantic comedy in  high school and you can only take it so far intill it implodes on itself, and another prolem I have with this series is that it has this meta commentary  asspect where its makeing  fun of the tropes and cliches of its genre, but also realays on sied tropes and cliches for its plot beat.

So comes off more like its mocking itself rather than any meaningful commentary on the subject and I for one hate that kind of humour in anime with a passion because it just isn't funny. When Hachiman is being an asshole that's when I find the series funny because I find his brand of no fucks given just comedy gold and this meta humour or references to other series just feels very forced. 


Speaking of forced the love triangle in this series between Hachiman, Yukino and Yui is the most forced thing In this series, because even though I find the "friendship" they forms together really sweet and endearing. But at the same time, I feel the romantic dynamic to there relationship feels tacked on for the sack of waifu wars or stretching out the story longer than it has to.



Characters, 6/10 

When it comes to main charter Hachiman, he is a breath of fresh ear if you are used to the generic Japanese high schooler template that may series use nowadays.  Becuase What makes Hachiman so great as a character is that he has a personality that you can define and isn't a just a blank self-insert.

He is this cynical,  anti-social asshole that just doesn't give a fuck, and what him really interesting as a character is that despite the zero fucks personality. There is a part of him that does care for people, it's just most people misunderstand his intentions. Becuase Hachiman is basically an anti-hero in a way because he is willing to shower the burdens of being hated in order to shit done.

I feel as far as teenage characters go Hachiman is very feel written for what he is, at times he feels almost human in a way instead of being this cardboard cutout.


When it comes to the other members of the service club Yukino and Yui.

Even though their personality is kinda standard fare, there is a lot more depth added to them and a lot more thought put into them so they come off charming than anything else. But besides that there not really that memorable when compared to Hachiman.


Side characters are in the same boat as Yukino and Yui but worse.

Their personalities are really watered down even if there is a tad bit of depth to them. I don't remember their names and I will forget they even exist within a week because I found them so boring. 


Now I will say that the dialogue and interactions between the charters are a lot more intriguing than the actual charters themselves. Because this series likes to dive into social interactions into more depth and thought than most series of its genre. For an example, there is a scene where characters could seem happy on the outside, but inside there really angry and are dropping this passive aggressive comments. Which I liked.




Art, 6/10

The animation runs quite smoothly and the art keeps up a decent quality,

But background looks like they were painted on at times. Of course, the second season lessens these issues I have to a degree with everything looking a lot more polished and slighty more detailed.

Art style is basic and the character designs are pretty standard fare, but I will say that the main charter little sister would look really great in some doujins though.




Sound, 5/10 


The first oping song was pretty good, but everything else hoping and ending wise was kinda lacklustre at best. There nice to listen  to i guess but they didnt really get my interest. The ost was done my some japanese music studio named MoNaca who have some very fumous people under them  like for example keiichi okabe, satoru kosaki and kakeru ishihama who from who i can gather so far  was the main dude behind the ost for this series.  Its not that bad of an ost to listain its just nothing really got my interest and make me feel like woh i need to download this and listain to it over and over again.



Enjoyment, 6/10


So when it comes to enjoyment, i enjoyed this seruies for what it was and i have even got 10 volumes  of the light novel. I think what really got me into this series it that it actually tries to provide some sort of thought-provoking content, which is very impressive for a series that is about high school bullshit.




Overall, 6/10

If you like romantic comedies I would say that my romantic comedy snafu is worth at least checking out, because it tries a lot harder than most of its genre. Which I think the effort alone should be prised to some degree But that doesn't mean it is the masterpiece that some people would claim it to be.

 Because it is highly limited in what it can do because of the high school setting, if its setting was in college or maybe the Japanese workplace it would properly have a lot more impact in its social commentary and it could talk about more things.

"If you can't get along without putting someone else down, it can't be real friendship."
I think most people’s high school experiences were pretty much similar. Sure, there’ll be exceptions, but a majority were probably loners, who either kept to themselves or kept up a “facade” to hide their “true self” among their “friends”; or maybe they were the type who would try to associate themselves with the “right people”, not caring who they’d step on as they climbed towards popularity.
Oregairu kind of deals with these things, in it’s own little way, making comments on how humans interact, and how society works...
Story: (7 / 10)
The seriesstarts out with our MC, Hikigaya, being forced to join a “Volunteer Service” club, in order to change his view on society, or even his entire personality, and this is where he’ll meet the other main characters of the show.


From here on, however, the anime is basically episodic, dealing with whatever request the club receives, or simply about what the characters do on their off-days.


Most of the time, it’ll all revolve around (or atleast come down to) how Hikigaya is able to meet and communicate with other people, as this is somewhat of a pretense for the series.


However, even if there are moments where he is shown developing a sort of friendship, and changing himself, it’s also somewhat “dropped”, as he often explains that there’s nothing wrong with solitude, and nobody should have to change who they are.


All in all, I thought the contents of each episode was rather good, whether it was about going shopping, playing tennis, or baking, it was done in such a way that it’d be kept interesting, which is (obviously) important in an episodic anime.


Art: (7 / 10)


I thought the overall art quality was pretty good, although nothing amazing. Character designs are also very good (and oh god pigtails), though I sometimes thought the side-characters could look a little bland. Still, it’s not really a big problem, and is easily overlooked.


Something I’ve come to expect in anything involving lots of girls of any shape or size, is obviously fanservice. However, there isn’t really much of that to find here... Sure, there are some slightly oversized body parts here and there, and of course there’s the swimsuit scenes, but it’s really nothing obscene, which I thought was nice.


Sound: (7 / 10)


I thought the voice actors did a very good job in portraying their respective characters; Hikigaya as a cynical loner, Yukino as a sort of cold “know-it-all”, Yui as the innocent cute girl, etc.


It really does add a lot when you’re able to provide such personalities without say, needless screaming and constant exaggeration for the cute girl.


As for the music, well I personally didn’t like the opening or ending themes all that much, because they were either not really my thing, or I didn’t really like the singers. However, I have to say that the background music was very well made, and it all fit very well with the anime overall.


Characters: (9 / 10)


So, this is where this series really shines. Relying heavily on its “cynical, loner” main character, it makes for a very relatable experience (at least for a lot of high school boys, I’d say).


Instead of your typical friendly, “wants to help everyone” type of character, you have one who’d rather not get involved, and looks down on society, and the way it does things.


Aside from that, you have several other, rather fleshed out characters, who all interact with the MC in different ways, and this is what really makes the anime. It’s not the complex story or the amazing artwork; It’s the interactions between all the different personalities.


They really did a great job in portraying a lot of common “high school personalities”, I think, and while not many characters get much character development at all, it’s really not needed to make it an enjoyable experience. In fact, it fits rather well with the theme of “one shouldn’t have to change just to fit it in”.


Enjoyment: (9 / 10)


Although sort of slow at times, this was a really enjoyable show. The characters make for a very relatable setting, the music was good, and it had its fair share of funny moments.


However, two major complaints I have are that first of all, this is said to be a rom-com, yet it barely focus on any romance at all. Sure, it’s obvious that some characters feel a certain way, but it often seems pretty one-sided, and most of the “love” from the MC seems to be directed at this cute little guy instead, which ofcourse makes for funny moments, but doesn’t help a lot in the romance department.


My other complaint was the final episode. I understand that it might be hard to wrap up a series in which there isn’t really any sort of story to wrap up, but seriously, the last episode didn’t have any form of closure at all.


To be honest, it actually felt like more of a filler episode, which they just kinda realised they had lying around, but had forgot to release...

Before starting My Teen Romantic Comedy SNAFU (which I will shorten to Oregairu for the remainder of this review), its name and the synopsis given here on MAL made this anime sound like a typical harem romantic comedy that combines a generic storyline with overused jokes - at least in my opinion - despite the lack of a harem tag. What a surprise it was to me after the first few episodes when I realized that Oregairu was different and much better than I had anticipated - despite not having much of the romance and comedy as suggested by the title.
NOTE: This will probably bea review of both the first and second seasons since they essentially remain the same aside from the shift of the main focus from the first to second season.


The story begins with high school loser loner Hachiman Hikigaya who is forced into joining the Services Club which aids students when they need it - and whose only member is the extremely gifted and beautiful but antisocial Yukino Yukinoshita - by his teacher, and in my opinion, parent-like figure Shizuka Hiratsuka in order to help him remedy his broken social skills. Their first request for help comes from Yui Yuigahama, who eventually joins the club, and it is through this first request, that it was made apparent to me that Oregairu was better than your typical rom com.


Oregairu doesn't tend to focus on comedy, yet still remaining hilarious, nor does it focus on romance, yet always hinting to us the possibility of a relationship. Instead, it focuses heavily on more complex issues of friendship and human behavior - which often isn't explored in very many anime - often putting the characters in realistic situations in which they have to make decisions about such issues, and giving us a taste of the thought process and psychology behind Hikigaya's seemingly cold and detached exterior, which is pretty realistic (trust me, I experienced it for a while myself).


Oregairu explores these topics extremely well while telling us an engrossing story of how our three protagonists in Yui, Hikigaya, and Yukino help other students with whatever problems they might have, despite occasionally clashing in how they want to achieve it, an issue which is the main focus of the second season.


I'd like to praise the boisterous subtlety of this anime. Though what I just said may sound oxymoronic, this anime does a fantastic job of telling us a story that is deeper than what it actually appears to be, without having to state the complete obvious, an unfortunate problem I find happens with many anime. However, and this being the only problem I found with the anime, this subtlety does border on cryptic in that at times, and especially during the second season, I could not for the life of me comprehend what the characters were implying during some of their conversations until I had read the episode synopsis on Wikipedia.


And thus, on this more subtler note is how the relationship between the three characters develops, and by the end of the second season, during which the development of their relationship is explored on a much more prominent note, it brought a tear to my eye when I saw just how much closer they had gotten as friends, despite the rocky paths they went through to to get to that point.


Much of this brilliant development in their relationships can be attributed to the strong development in their individual characters, which is, again, pretty subtle for most characters.


Hikigaya's development is the most evident, provided he is the main character. For the entirety of the first season and for part of the second, Hikigaya pretty much sees his inclusion in the Services Club as some sort of punishment imposed on him by Shizuka - as seen by the unorthodox and self-harmful manner in which he solves peoples' problems - but eventually begins to open up to the other members - essentially going from happily being the loneliest and most detached guy in the world to actually desiring friends like Yui and Yukino, who both end up caring very much for him despite his constant skepticism regarding their relationships, even if it means having to suffer.


More subtle are Yui's and Yukino's developments, both of whom open up very slowly to each other. Yui tries to act cheerful and constantly put on a smile, something which is completely forced at the beginning and slowly becomes less and less forced as the anime continues. Meanwhile, Yukino's past and her present are pretty much shrouded in mystery, one huge driving factor in her development, and which is constantly emphasized by her seemingly bitch of an older sister, Haruno. And yet her subtle and eventually apparent inclination to try and open her heart to Yui and Hikigaya towards the end of the second season really highlights the struggle that each character suffers to make their friendships "real".


And it isn't just the trio of main characters who should be praised but also the large cast of supporting characters - though I have to say I'm not a fan of the few who are there essentially for comedic effect like Saika Totsuka, the guy with the appearance of a girl, Hina Ebina, the girl with the homosexual fantasies, or Yoshiteru Zaimozuka, the guy who suffers from chuunibyou. On the other hand, there are characters like Hayama Hayato, the ace of the soccer team and who everyone has high expectations of, Shizuka, the teacher and parent-like figure who really seems to hurt whenever she sees Hikigaya do damage to his own reputation and feelings, or Komachi, Hikigaya's lively and adorable little sister. Whether these supporting characters receive development or not, they highlight some of the problems facing our main trio and really drive the story and their friendships forward throughout the anime, and for the most part are really like-able.


I haven't got much to say about Oregairu's art or sound. For the most part the art was really detailed and looked pretty darn nice, the background music suited their respective scenes, and the openings and closings are pretty freaking amazing (it's a shame I can only find the second season opening on YouTube).


Oregairu is a personal favorite, possibly being a top 5 or 10 anime for me. It definitely surpassed any low expectations I had for it, dragging me into a story which really had my full attention from start to finish as I desperately wanted to see Yui, Yukino, and Hikigaya truly become friends. I would laugh when Yukino made insulting comments about Hikigaya or when Hikigaya would instinctively say something to himself based on his own past experiences. Oregairu requires you utmost attention, particularly in the second season, when you have to infer what the characters are implying during their conversations. I absolutely adore this anime and though everything I've said in this review may be due to bias on my part (I sincerely hope other people also share my views), I strongly recommend everyone gives Oregairu a try.


Any feedback on my reviews is much appreciated! Thanks for reading!

Favorite Quote: "Hard work betrays none,  but dreams betray many." -Hachiman Hikigaya
That quote is one of my favorite quotes spoken by an anime character.  I personally believe that this is somewhat true for alot of us.  So before I would like to go on with my review, I was never a fan of the romantic comedy genre.  I always thought of them as being cheesy and painfully predictable.  However, Yahari Ore no Seishun definitely took me by surprise.  Here's some of the main reasons why I believe this anime is such a masterpiece.
Story: The main storyline can be prettymuch summed up in the anime description.  Initially, when reading the summary I felt it was gonna be a very generic, but I realized the romance in this series isn't thrown s right into your face from the very beginning.  To be more precise, the romance is pretty light in the  entire series.  There are only hints of romance between character now and then.  Overall, the anime does a fantastic job of romance through the services completed in the club.  I thought this was a really cool idea to implement rather than simply throwing the obvious romance to the audience.  This allows the romance to develop at a great pace and makes us wonder who the main character will fall for if any.

10/10


Art: There wasn't anything particularly unusual about the art.  I thought everything was pretty well done, nothing out of the ordinary in this anime.  I liked the colors that were used in the opening theme and for the ending as well.

10/10


Sound: I loved the opening theme and the ending theme alot when I watched the series.  In my opinion, the ending theme sort of explains the complications of the romance that is experienced throughout the anime.  The OSTs played during each segment also made it very comical and enjoyable to watch.

10/10


Character: The characters in this series was what intrigued me the most.  I found the characters very unique, interesting, realistic throughout the series.  For those new to the anime you might be wondering how are the characters different from other romantic comedy series?  To respond to this, I would say that the main character in this series was what made it so unique.  He isn't the boring, dull, and extremely dense type of person, but actually the complete opposite.  In fact, I would say confidently that he is well aware of the ongoing romance, society, and his overall environment.  What makes it even more interesting is his ability to think very critically about others and situations presented at the moment.  Not only is it very critical, but the way he says it in his thoughts makes it way more engaging and realistic.  Alot of characters in romantic comedies cannot do this.   I understand that it has to do with the writing of the developers, but it was done very well.  This anime also perfectly illustrates, in my opinion, the different kinds of people there are in the world.  From socially distant type people to arrogant ones this series has it all.  Excellent pacing for character development made characters extremely likeable and it made you feel as if you can identify with some of them.  It also made room for characters to change their initial attitudes as the series progressed.  In my case, I identified perfectly with the main characters point of view and philosophies. 

10/10


My Opinion: It's not who I am underneath, but what I do that defines me.  Batman can be related to the main character. Throughout of the series, I find that the he is a kind hearted person, but he isn't concerned about that.  I feel what he is concerned about is the society around him and how it is pretty messed up according to him.  As someone who holds similar viewpoints as the main character, it is one of the reasons why I really appreciated this romantic comedy masterpiece.  This show has tons of comedy, a bit of romance, and tons of theories and philosophies about life.  I fully recommend watching this anime not just for the romance, but for what it can offer to us as humans.  Seriously, this anime actually got me saying "yeah that's true" alot times and "hey the main character is actually right, it's so true about what he said about people and society."  Yahari Ore no Seishun wouldn't be on my top five best romcoms of all time, it would fall in my top five of all time.


I hope this review was helpful for you guys.  Thank you for reading and I hope you guys will enjoy it as much as I did.


Final Score: 10/10

Slice of life/Romcom anime seem to always follow the same layout. It was honestly a genre that I started to get bored. Apart from the very few unique anime in that genre I didnt care for the majority. Then Yahari came along, which breaks all stereotypes of the SOL/RomCom genre. You have a MC who seems like he couldnt care less about others and he doesnt fall head over heels over any of the girls. Hachiman might be one of the best MC's to ever hit this genre, along with an amazing cast of characters, Yukino who in some ways is like Hachiman in thatthey distant themselves away from everybody but they still conflict again each other. Yui who breaks the tense moments with her bubbly, over the top personality. And lets not forget about the supporting cast, Saika who everyone loves. Theres not one thing you can dislike about him. Everytime him and Hachiman are on the same scene you can expect some laughs. Komachi, Hachiman's little sister who at the beginning is probably the only person that cares about her brother. Even if she pokes fun at him, she still cares very deeply about him. And last but not lease, the sensei, much like Komachi, cares about Hachiman but shows it in a way more aggressive manner (by punching hachiman a few times). An anime with an amazing cast that breaks most stereotypes, good music, and of course Hachiman's monologues which are incredibly easy to relate to especially if at any point in your life you might of considered yourself a loner. This anime ended in a open ended manner. it was a satisfying ending but you still wanted more. Luckily there will be more novels, and maybe in a year or two, we'll see a season 2 and see a final conclusion to this amazing and unique SOL/RomCom

Probably the most surprising anime I've watched in a long time. And I just recently finished Higurashi so that should mean something.
As a strict shunner of the harem genre, any anime with a "so-and-so best girl" mantra is one that I do not want to be any part of. And oh boy were there a fair share of hints eagerly putting me off – the generic looking poster of a guy standing behind two girls of different archetypes, the synopsis: Romantic comedy? An edgy, lethargic loner? Forced into a club with the PRETTIEST GIRL IN SCHOOL? Dear Lord.
Who knows what it was that drove meto check out that first episode, but whatever it was, I'm kinda grateful.


When you have a protagonist so cynical that he points out a godawful romcom cliché the moment the viewer notices it, you know the series is going to have a healthy dose of self-awareness. Then, the series even takes a step further, becoming so sardonic it turns into brutal honesty. So in additon to the entertaining interactions amongst an amusing cast and its mellow slice-of-life tone, there is a bitterly candid and unapologetically blunt narrative on society.


So, no, this series is certainly not a harem, or at least not the brand of atrocity we've linked the term with. It is very much a comedy, with a few romantic (borderline josei) elements, none of which bog the pacing. The romance doesn't really get anywhere until the 2nd season, where even then it's barely prevalent.


The protagonist is, thankfully, not the 2edgy4u people-hater he's made out to be. He's simply a slightly pessimistic wallflower, but at all times conscious of himself and his surroundings. And a lot of the characters actually have a third dimension! Some depth! Cancelling out what is undoubtedly the greatest vice of most love triangle centred anime – the need for appealing characters, not interesting ones. Although many side characters are admittedly not as fleshed out (in the first season), they do well in their role as societal representations. All in all, it's a pretty engrossing show with some ...genuine... laugh out loud moments.


Bonus: Episode 11 has what is very likely the greatest clapback in anime history

It's really sad to see that this anime is simply flying over people's head just because they think this is going to be a typical rom-com anime that we have seen over a hundred times. I can assure you that it's not. 
(There will be SPOILERS in my review)
[Story]: (8/10) (SPOILERS)
Hikigaya Hachiman, an anti-social and a loner high school student is forced by his teacher to join the Service/Volunteers Club. There, he meets Yukino Yukinoshita who is also a loner but for a different reason and Yui Yuigahama, an extremely energetic and cheerful girl. 
This is probably one of the major reasons why some ormost people skipped this anime. This anime doesn’t have romance..At least, for the first season. It doesn’t even focus on romance at all. So if you’re expecting an anime like Toradora where the 2 characters get together and starts dating then this is not the anime for you. I'm a big fan of romance anime but I still love both seasons of this show, even though the romance wasn't really there.


The show is not your typical Rom-Com anime. It didn't even feel like a Rom-Com anime. It felt like a slice-of-life show....a different kind of slice-of-life show. The show mostly focuses on the members of the Service Club helpi.........trying to help out other characters' problems like Hachiman and Yukinon teaching Yui how to bake cookies or volunte.......being forced to volunteer at a summer camp along with their classmates. 


That's just the outer layer of the show. What makes the show really unique and interesting is the inner layer. What's this inner layer you ask? Hachiman's view on society that's almost realistic and his monologues that deals with interesting issues in our life. I've been a loner myself (4 years ago) and half of Hachiman's monologues are true like how he talks about social hierarchy in today's youth or how girls are nice to you but in reality, they just don't care. Unfortunately, I've experienced these moments myself...Especially the latter. The other half contains Hachiman's hilarious (and sometimes ridiculous) monologues. 


I did say that the show "mostly" focuses on the members of the Service Club right? Of course, I did..The show ALSO focuses on the character interaction between the members of the Service Club (i.e Hachiman and Yuki spouting some ideological crap at each other, etc.). No love triangle here though....


I can tell you right now that the show moves at an incredibly snail pacing in terms of romance. The show's pacing itself is fine but if you're expecting the characters to start realizing their feelings towards each other in like 13 episodes then you've got the wrong anime. That doesn't even occur until the Second Season. Hell, none of them starts dating at the Second Season...I won't spoil anymore contents from the Second Season. 


With that out of the way, I now want to focus on the comedy part of the show. In short, the show is extremely funny...but then again, it all depends on the person's sense of humour. As someone who has a great sense of humour, I can tell for the fact that the show really is funny. There's a bunch of reasons why I found the show extremely hilarious. Firstly, Hachiman knows fully well how rom-com moments goes so when he see's one, he doesn't fall for it. On the other hand, the gods of rom-com constantly puts him in what seems to be situations that you only see in Romantic Comedies..For this reason, he curses the gods of rom-com. I love how I wrote that sentence..That one definitely scored high in my book. 

My point here is the show doesn't have one of those romantic comedy cliches that you usually see these days. The show, or rather Hachiman instead makes fun of those cliches. I did spot one cliche where Hachiman walked in the club room and saw the girls changing. This was, however, used as a joke. Or in Hachiman's words "Now this is how romantic comedies should be". 


Secondly, there are loads of Yaoi (Boys Love) moments here. They are obviously only used as a joke. Let me tell you right now, I'm a straight person who likes girls. I'm not a gay person, therefore..I completely abhor Yaoi anime shows. For whatever weird reason though, I "secretly" enjoyed the Yaoi moments. I also *ahem* "secretly" ship Totsuka and Hachiman. Hachiman's monologues and how he reacts when Totsuka is around him makes the Yaoi scenes even funnier. There's also that female character named "Ebina" who is a big fan of Yaoi. I like her...she ships the main characters (i.e Hiki x Hayato, etc.) and she has passion. She also adds a bit of hilarity to the show. 


By episode 9 or 10, the show starts to get serious and the show's atmosphere will continue on towards the entirety of Season 2. So if that's what you were expecting then you will love the late 2nd half of the first season and season 2. Revealing more will take me another paragraph so I just want to stop here.  

______________________________________________________________ 

[Art/Animation]: (7.5/10)

The show's animation is not the greatest but it is fairly average. I didn't have any problems with the environment or how the surrounding areas look. I did have some minor issue with the character design though. They lack details and most of their eyes just looks so big and out of place...I can't really explain it properly. The characters are not joking when they said that Hachiman's eyes looks like the eye of a dead fish. It really does. Whatever, I got used to the character design in like 2-3 episodes. 

______________________________________________________________

[Sound]: (9/10)

The show did a pretty good job on the soundtrack department. The theme that usually plays in the background fits really well depending on the show's mood and atmosphere. Now the OP and ED theme song(s).


The OP theme song is "Yukitoki" by Nagi Yanagi and the ED theme song is "Hello Alone" by Yukino and Yui. The ED theme song has 2 variants. First is the Ballade version sung by Yui and the second is the Band Arrange version sung by the same two characters. I like the Opening theme song. The singer's voice sounds great and the song itself is pretty catchy. I also love the ED theme song and in my opinion, it is a lot better than the OP theme song.  The variants also sounds great..2nd variant being the best out of the two. 

______________________________________________________________

[Characters]: (9.5/10) (SPOILERS)

"A Hayo x Hachi is a must buy...No, a must GAY! -Hina Ebina


Now this is where the show truly shined...The characters. There were a lot of characters introduced in the show but most of them weren't introduced all in one episode. It was across the first half of the series and the way they are introduced is if they have a request that needs attention then they go to the Service Club. I mean, that's how Yui Yuigahama or that guy who has an eight-grade syndrome got introduced. Anyways, here's my opinion on some of the main characters. 


Hikigaya Hachiman, a self-proclaimed loner and an anti-social high school teen. Being a loner is nothing new in anime. In fact, it's overused. A bad-ass loner seems to be a hit in anime today for whatever reason. Hachiman is a different kind of loner and he's someone that you should focus on. The ideals that he spouts out are somewhat realistic and I actually share some of those ideals. He avoids social situations whenever he can and he's not an idiotic pervert like most of the protagonists these days. His monologues are also pretty damn hilarious and dare I say..insightful? The guy really understands how youth works. 


Then there's Yukino Yukinoshita, a loner but for a different reason. She simply doesn't want friends. She's a smart, extremely talented girl and belongs to a rich family. Whenever someone wants to argue with her (in this case, the arguments between Yukino and Hachiman) then they better give up the second they start because she doesn't hold her tongue back. She's also a funny sarcastic girl. 


Then there's Yui Yuigahama, an energetic, cheerful and talkative high school girl. Unlike Yukino and Hachiman, she's not a loner. She's outgoing and she socializes all the time with her peers. She's actually the main driving force of the club..Otherwise, the club would be boring or it would contain repetitive arguments between Yukino and Hachiman. 


Then there's the rest of the side characters.. In my opinion, they're great. It adds variety to the show's cast and their personalities are all great..even though they all have cliched personalities. For example, Hayama is the most famous guy on the school and is "nice" towards everyone. I put a quote on the word "nice" for a reason. Another example is one of Hayama's friend, Yumiko. She has that "whatev's" personality that you see in most characters these days who thinks they are all "high and mighty". 


I really love the show's character progression and development. Just by watching the entirety of the first season, you will see the main and side characters change..from huge changes to small changes. Most noticeably is Hachiman's changes. He's still the same ol' loner but what's different is how he looks towards his friends and peers. Especially Yukino and Yui. 

______________________________________________________________

[Enjoyment]: (9/10)

I definitely enjoyed this anime. It's something new and fresh. It's also different than your typical rom-com animes. Hachiman's monologues and his interactions with some of the characters added hilarity to the show. 

______________________________________________________________

[VERDICT]

"My Teen Romantic Comedy SNAFU" or SNAFU (Oregairu) for short is a Romantic-Comedy anime that should not be skipped nor missed. It's different than your typical rom-com, the characters are great, fleshed out, and their actions are believable and the comedy is hilarious. The show also doesn't have one of those rom-com cliches like a protagonist tripping and falling on top of the main girl, boob grabbing, and the fanservice is either kept to a minimum or is non-existent. The only downside to this show is its inconclusive ending. 


[OVERALL]: (9/10)



Pros:

+Not your typical Romantic Comedy show

+Tons of Funny Moments

+Great Soundtrack

+Great OP and ED theme song

+Character's actions are believable

+Hachiman and his monologues

+Contains no Rom-Com cliches


Cons:

-Mediocre Character Design

-Inconclusive Ending

Now, when this show was aired back in 2013, I REALLY thought it was going to be a generic RomCom. Why was this the case? Well, if a story revolved around a high school student who was forced into a club by his teacher, and ends up meeting a ice-cold beauty who is the president of said club, who wouldn't think this was a gonna be another RomCom. However, that said, this show really blew away my expectations and eventually became my personal favorite title.
Story - 8
As said previously, this shows revolves around the members of the "Service Club", Hikigaya Hachiman, a loner who loathesthe idea of "youth" as he is affixed that it is a lie. Yukino Yukinoshita, an intelligent, seemingly perfect, beauty who is cold and brutally honest, and the last member being Yui Yuigahama, a girl who is seemingly all sunshine and rainbows. Together, they help people who come to the club with their issues. Now, this already sounds generic with this premise of the plot revolving around a club being run down to the ground with whats atop of my head right now, The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumya, Boku wa Tomodachi ga Sukunai, Gj-Bu and many other series that I am not gonna mention that revolve around a club. However, what this series does that defies the stereotypical is the characters. Even though all the club does is solve problems, what makes it entertaining is how they do it and come to that point. If it were any stereotypical protagonist, I wouldn't enjoy the show as much as I would have. But with Hikigaya Hachiman along with his viewpoint of the world, makes it entertaining. One thing to take note however, is that the series does not proceed to make the romance as major plot point in the series, as that is what would normally be expected in a RomCom. The romance is certainly is there and can be seen, but it is more of a sub-plot point and doesn't make a big deal out of this, but more rather, focusing more on the cast and their chemistry all together rather than 2 people. I sorta wish that they give that more focus, but it still was great either way.


Art - 8

The art is really distinctive among other RomComs I have watched due to Hikigaya's prominent feature, his fish eyes. The show's art is really nothing special but it it got the job done and that it suited the series very well, with it's vibrant and radiant colours and immediately changes it's tone very easily when Hikigaya delves into his monologues.


Sound - 9

I definitely liked the OST as it the situation the characters were in whether it was a dramatic moment, or if it was a moment of it's routine based comedy, and yet entertaining moments among the cast, the soundtrack did it's justice for the series. The voice actors were also chosen really well, with Hikigaya Hachiman being voiced by Takuya Eguchi, who played him very well, especially when it came down it the monologues, he portrayed the character really well when I compare it to the Light Novel. Nao Touyama and Hayami Saori also did a great job with their respective characters, Nao Touyama voicing Yui and Hayami Saori voicing Yukino.


Characters - 10

I absolutely loved the characters that had been written in this series with them being written more realistically then what is stated in the synopsis. 


With Hikigaya Hachiman, he is probably the most relateable character and the most realistic I have seen, and without him, this show wouldn't be that good. His cynical and pessimistic mindset of society is always entertaining and yet, it contains truth among the words that he speaks. It truly kept me wanting for more as I hear more dark, truthful and humorous comments about society. The interactions he has is humorous and fun to watch, especially when he is in the club with it's members, being one of the best chemistry between a trio ever.

Yukino more or less counteracts Hikigaya's personality as they both have opposing ideals. However, this makes their interactions more interesting as they both continuously both exchange their own verbal fists against one another. To see who's ideology is better. 

There is not much to say about Yui, but I really liked her character as well, although she was the least prominent member out of the trio. However, she plays a vital role amongst Hikigaya and Yukino as she is the glue the holds the club together and without her, they will more or less argue until one other wears each other out.

Even though there is some amounts of development, it certainly was there as Yukino steadily broke her icy shell, Yui became more independent and at the end of the series, Hikigaya started to grow more fond of the interactions that he is involved with Yui and Yukino, no matter how pointless it seemed. 

Even the side characters, such as the delusional otaku, Zaimokuza, gender ambiguous Totsuka and The Joker of Hikigaya, Haruno, was very entertaining to watch, as they interact with Hikigaya and the club members and their reactions towards each person.


Enjoyment - 10

Overall, I was always hoping to come back for more as having to see this club continue with its pointless and yet oddly charming interactions were fun . I always liked having a good cast in any anime, and this certainly did what I wanted fulfilled. 


Overall - 9

The series could've done with it's animation and done a little more with the plot, but what totally threw all that out of the bus was the characters that had been realistically written, which I had enjoyed throughout the series. This show was definitely not your stereotypical romantic comedy that throws the norm out of the window, which I personally think is a spectacle. This show would definitely be recommended to people who wish for a different spin on the romantic comedy genre and for people who loves anime that is dialogue-heavy instead of the shounens.

	The characters all had complex personalities and ideals that really made me stop and ponder instead of just staringat the screen like a zombie. The views that Hikigaya possessed were both refreshing and oddly enough, correct (most of the time). The simple fact that Hikigaya is able to read between the lines and stay detached from the mainstream of society was exciting and thought provoking. \n
	While Hikigaya comes across as harsh, pessimistic, anti-social, and unfeeling he’s actually quite sensitive and caring. He frequently sacrifices himself in order to help improve the way others think, defuse a situation, or fulfill a request. While his methods seem overly harsh he employs the method of “common enemy” in order to unite his classmates and strengthen relationships regardless of how much it actually hurts him. Truly this is one of the most intriguing characters I have ever had the pleasure to watch. 	\n
	The OP and ED were both fun and lively just like the series. The VCs were also excellent and the animation was bright and fit the flow of the series well. The witty dialogue between characters was comical while still retaining the ability to make you really think about what they were discussing. \n
	Overall I really enjoyed this series and would recommend it to anyone who likes RomComs. I can’t say the same for the second season so if you really enjoyed this series and have a happy end of series hangover I would refrain from watching the second season. Let me start by saying that Yahari Ore no Seishun Love Comedy wa Machigatteiru. or Oregairu for short, does many things right. Coming out of the show, you know that what you’ve just watched was a cut above the typical rom-com you expected. Why? Well, that’s easy—because of the unique cast of characters that can be found within Oregairu.
In particular, it is Hikigaya Hachiman who deserves the MVP award. It is through him and his fantastically cynical inner monologues that we are granted a much more realistic, and therefore relatable perspective on youth. Time and time again, anime gives us these clichéd protagonists, whose idiocyhas us screaming at the screen. Well, not this time, as unlike with those guys, Hikigaya actually says what you are thinking, which can be truly rewarding to watch.


And it’s not just Hikigaya who’s worthy of praise. Sure, some of the characters definitely play up to anime tropes more than some would like, but others, such as the minor antagonists (Miura Yumiko and Salami Minami) are very true to people we have all encountered in our everyday lives. At some point, we have all met people who are unnecessarily mean to others, or who use other people for their own personal gain, so the way in which this show handles and punishes such characters is incredibly satisfying.


In relation to the story, art, and sound, they were all good in their own rights. The story might not have wrapped everything up, and it may have been littered with the standard scenarios (the vacation episode, the test of courage, and the cultural festival) that we’ve all seen a hundred times before, but it was never once a chore to sit through, and that's because of the characters. 


The art in particular was nice and colourful, with character designs that were fittingly appropriate. At times, there were noticeable drops in animation quality, but they were never enough to detract from my enjoyment of the show.


As for the sound, the OP and ED did their jobs amicably, even if they were never personally memorable. The OST on the other hand was used very effectively, with Episode 5, during Hikigaya’s inner monologue about ‘nice girls’ being a prime and touching example.


If I had to pick one flaw with Oregairu, it would have to relate to the consistency of its realism. What I mean by that is that whilst the show handles a lot of serious issues brilliantly, I couldn’t help but feel like it played it safe on others—in particular: romance. It honestly felt like a step back to the clichéd protagonists of lesser shows, when Hikigaya fails to acknowledge how he feels about a girl he knows likes him, but I digress. I’m simply nitpicking.


In truth, I would recommend Oregairu to anybody. Whilst it may conform to well-trodden anime conventions in places, it still stands high on the shoulders of other high school-based dramas. So much so, that I may have to revaluate some of my past scores… Enjoy!

Hikigaya Hachiman is now one of my favorite anime protagonists. Besides his wit and keen perception of society’s workings, his proud introversion and disdain for people in general remind me of myself. Having grown up with few true friends, I can empathize with Hachiman and how he became who he is. I, too, don’t see my fellow humans as being particularly noble, and I admit, I also feel a sort of twisted satisfaction in my being solitary. I, too, recognize the futility in seeking hope in a girl’s interaction with me, as it most likely means nothing more than simple friendliness.
High school for many isa time of what I will dub “perfecting the mold”. Students invest so much importance on getting good grades (i.e. all As), meeting the perfect boyfriend/girlfriend, having that divine first kiss and later first time, and so on. Too often, I feel, high school students raise the bar so high that when it’s not reached, they despair. In other words, it’s overhyped.


Hachiman lives through high school with the completely opposite perspective. He doesn’t expect anything and, sort of akin to Okazaki Tomoya, just slogs through life without much of a care for the world. And like Tomoya, he is able to change, albeit very gradually, after befriending Yukino and Yui.


Yukino is similar to Hachiman in that she is also friendless, although for different reasons. Known as the “Ice Queen”, she appears cold and aloof, although this is due to certain family circumstances. Yui on the other hand is bright and ebullient and she treats Yukino and Hachiman with an affability that, in part, weakens their antisocial shells.


And thus we have a sort of love comedy/triangle, whose specifics I won’t go into. But unlike other romance stories I’ve seen, whose developments are predictable and thus lackluster, the “developments” in Oregairu are not so fast. That is, guy gets girl doesn’t happen that quickly. The interactions among Hachiman, Yui, and Yukino are incredibly realistic. Reluctance to advance, hesitation to call another friend, a slow desire for something that one hasn’t had -- friendship. I can tell you from my life that reaching out to people and emerging from my introverted shell is difficult. And for Hachiman and Yukino, who are even more extreme cases, you can only expect the social barriers there.


But that’s precisely what made watching Oregairu so… resonant. Watching this quasi-love comedy play out, narrated by Hachiman and his unique life philosophy, reminded me of my own failures at romance back in middle and high school. Hikki reminded me of my own introversion, and my pride at being alone. Much of what he says is true. Politically and socially incorrect to point out, but true all the same. Hikigaya Hachiman is, essentially, the Holden Caulfield of anime.


Now most people don't grow up like Hachiman, so don’t be surprised if you can’t really empathize with and understand him and Yukino. Even so, Oregairu provides an intriguing and well-written look at the consequences of societal ostracization on one’s outlook on life and the world. And how the simple fact of making friends, however long that process, can influence and shape that outlook.

Whenever I start a show, there are a number of things that I like to look for which are important to me. One of the things I like to look for is when the characters reveal to us the reasoning behind an activity or behavior they engage in (or lack thereof) so that I have a better understanding of how that person thinks and behaves (I’ve noticed that this happens a lot in the form of internal monologues). 
It has been my experience that characters who exhibit cynicism and skepticism are an excellent source of the portrayal of this kind of behavior, as it usuallygoes without saying that those characters are typically damaged or have experienced some kind of hardship or misfortune in the past that would cause them to become jaded in their own way. They wear masks. They lie. They sometimes have twisted reasoning. And we are often left wondering “Well, why is he/she like that?” But as we learn more and more about a character and their past, we begin to fully understand and appreciated them better not just as a person, but as a collection of their values and what they hold dear. And sometimes, if we take the time to compare their values to our own, we have the rare opportunity to reflect on ourselves and ask the age-old question “What is important to me, and how important is it?”


Oregairu offers all of that. As we follow the story through the eyes of the anti-social protagonist Hikigaya Hachiman and his attempts to navigate the uncertain world of society and high school life, we soon realize that there is a certain, unapologetic realism to the whole story revolving around this romantic comedy, which goes against what a lot of your typical rom-coms tend to do. There is a lot of focus given to the choices made within the story, and the choices we make in life are usually made from our experiences; I won’t touch a red-hot stove because I know it will burn me, and I switched my major from Biology to Biochemistry because I realized how much I liked chemistry while simultaneously realizing how little I enjoyed learning about plants and animals. While some of these decisions I’ve mentioned may or may not be relatable to you, the choices Hachiman makes in this series are backed with his own set of reasons. And while we may not necessarily agree with his thinking at times, we understand where he’s coming from and can clearly see that he is simply acting out of his own experiences and out of necessity.


It is therefore interesting to see how different people choose to deal with failure, as well as the lengths people will go to in order to fit into society. Some people can shrug off failure and see it as a learning experience while others carry it around like a sack of potatoes. Still others choose to stay away from people, to keep their interactions professional and polite, or to go along with social behavior and laugh at “Larry’s ‘funny’ joke.” The real world is often unforgiving to those who can’t play its game properly, and it is interesting to see how Hachiman, Yukino, and Yui, with their own set of unique experiences, navigate and struggle through the confusing world of relationships and society.


It would be a mistake, then, to assume that with all its realism, this series is lacking in humor - this is a comedy, after all. A lot of the humor in this series actually stems from Hachiman’s monologues and warped, twisted personality which is often challenged by the other main characters (usually Yukino and Yui), and which, if nothing else, are often quite amusing to listen to. The humor is delivered dryly, deadpan, and satirically with a healthy dose of self-deprecation (which fits my style). Because after all, you are simply getting a ridiculous take on how the world works from someone cynical and damaged.


Perhaps what makes the show’s characters so strikingly unique is that despite everyone’s intentions, no one is really innocent in this show. Like most character-driven stories, everyone is trying to act on their own accord, trying to shape the world to fit their needs, and ultimately trying to fumble for meaning in this uncertain place we live in (sounds kinda like us, huh?). There is an abundance of situations that cause the main character to try to rationalize his behavior and find meaning in his perceived circumstances, and these situations often involve the people around him. I’d like to place emphasis on this last point because this show serves as a testament to how relationships, whether real or virtual, should ideally be formed: they should grow organically. Nothing seems rushed. Nor out of place. Nor unnecessary. It is the organic nature and progression of everyone’s relationship with each other that makes every character feel real in their own way. This is crucial to any show’s attempt at trying to get the viewer to connect with its characters. And in this respect, Oregairu does an impeccable job.


But what makes this show so attractive to me is not just the characters or delivery of humor, but that it allows us to take a lighthearted approach to something that is both relatable and a serious issue to millions of people around the world. Most people have experienced some kind of loneliness in their lives (or at least, the uncertainty surrounding it), and this show gives us a chance to laugh (sometimes bitterly) in the face of it all through the lens of Hikigaya Hachiman. It gives us a chance to laugh at our own masks that we’ve created and worn. To laugh at our own possible loneliness. And to reflect on our own wounds and scars, pick ourselves up, brandish a smirk on our face, and say in an empowered manner to the world “is that all you’ve got?” It reminds us of the old adage “comedy is just tragedy plus time,” and it is often up to us to determine how much time we need in order to move forward. 


Overall, this is a beautiful anime brimming with wit, meaning, and attention to detail, and if anything I mentioned above seems interesting to you, then I highly recommend that you give this series a shot. But for those simply looking for a quick and easy laugh, it would be hard for me to recommend this series to you for the following reasons: Despite the humor in this show being largely accessible, this is really not your typical rom-com chock-filled with gag humor, fan-service, innocence, and plot-driven antics (do not confuse this with complete absence). This show’s approach to romance feels quite real, with all its complexities and hardships. Relationships are often not clear-cut or as simple as we’d like them to be. They take mutual effort to form and maintain, and this show understands and illustrates this very well. Furthermore, this show (especially Season #2) demands a certain level of attention to detail and the ability to read between the lines if you’re attempting to appreciate it to its fullest extent. Wataru Watari’s attention to detail is, for lack of better words, simply stunning, and it wouldn’t do this series enough justice to watch it with casual abandon. 


It would also be hard for me to recommend this series to people who have never experienced or struggled with loneliness or who have trouble empathizing with others. This is because I think it would be hard for you to find yourself relating to the characters (which is kind of the whole point of a character-driven series, in my opinion), while simultaneously running the risk of becoming impatient with them. 


If nothing else, this show offers you a safe glimpse of the life of a loner as he struggles to deal with the demands of relationships and society. I therefore encourage you to look at the world through the eyes of Hikigaya Hachiman and laugh at him (and possibly yourself) while doing so.

School life might just be the best time of anyone's life. You hang out with your friends, establish priceless memories together, and you even fall in love with those who seemed like they were never going to love you back. Yahari Ore no Seishun addresses this in an extraordinarily beautiful manner.
Let's break it down, shall we?
Story: 10/10
I loved the story. At first glance, you're already drawn in by the unique concept, yet it just keeps getting better and better. Meet Hikigaya Hachiman, a loner. Meet Yuigahama Yui, a girl who makes any situation three times brighter. And then meet Yukinoshita Yukino, cold-hearted yet helpful. Onceyou meet these three characters, you start to think "How in Hell are they going to make an amazing story out of this? These three have almost nothing in common, with even the main characters not being friends, the series can't progress at all." Well, you're right on so many levels, except for that last bit. Wataru Watari, the light novel writer, has managed to put in such an astounding story that I don't even know where to begin.


But let's start at the start. This anime is a RomCom, an anime focusing on romance and comedy at the same time. These two are the main genres of this anime, keep that in mind. Each new episode gave the Service Club different tasks to do, in hopes of aiding the student who requested the help. This idea is really unique, I've never seen such a thing before. But, that could just be my narrow view of things. Through the process of the tasks comes the comedy, through screw-ups or funny moments the characters encounter. The addition of more characters, from the stereotypical "popular kids group", gives a more realistic situation. Through these tasks, the characters also began to slowly realise their feelings for each other. This is where the romance comes in. And as time progresses, so does the intensity of every new conflict. In the end, only one conflict arose: their romance.


The romance in this anime might be one of my favourites due to the inordinate amount of conflicts in every characters' emotions. The ending was flawlessly executed, because it was very thought-provoking and heart-breaking. The people whom you ship together might start to go against their own love, for their own good or for the sake of other people. All-in-all, the story here was astounding and interesting.


Art: 8/10

I enjoyed the art. Colours were iridescent, characters looked great, sceneries was vibrant, and movements were smooth and accurate. Well, all these compliments above happened most of the time in the series. Sometimes the art strays slightly off flawless, which is why it's still an 8.


Character: 10/10

Alright, the characters here are interesting. Like, REALLY interesting. Loner Hachiman seems to be the protagonist of the show, but he plays many different roles: the hero, the villain and the middle man. This alone grabs the watcher's interest, as protagonists are always "supposed" to be the good guy. But when conflicts arise when being the good guy might lead to more problems, Hachiman steps in and blows minds. Let's talk about Yukinon, Miss Ice Queen. I loved the way her character developed over time, from the strict and inferior demeanour at first, then she gets softer as time progresses when she realises she was pretending to be inferior this whole while, when in fact she's the same as the rest of them. This sort of development intrigues me and I'm sure they intrigue many others. As for Yui, she comes off as a cheerful happy-go-lucky girl, who is also helpful and friendly to those around her. Yet, as time goes on, her personality grows darker, and she doesn't play around as the nice girl anymore. And maybe, to be helpful, you have to contradict your own emotions.


The other supporting characters from the popular kids' group also had interesting personalities. Hayama, for instance, seemed like the kind and hot guy, but isn't as nice as he acts out to be. In the end, the character development and their contradictory personalities are just what makes this show wonderful.


Sound: 9/10

There's nothing much to say about the sounds, other than the fact that all the openings and endings were BEAUTIFUL.


Yukitoki, the first opening, has a cheery and upbeat tune to it. This shows how the series is all cheery and happy at first. The first ending, Hello Alone, is also upbeat because the romantic conflicts haven't started yet. But the two vocalists sound like Yukino and Yui, raising some eyebrows about those two. And the title is probably a nod to Hachiman's loneliness. The second opening is Harumodoki, which has a slightly sadder tone to it. This is when the conflicts start to arise. The last ending song is Everyday World, also having a slightly sad tone to it. Along with two singers, both of which sound like Yukino and Yui, you feel nostalgic. These songs are a perfect pick for the series.


Enjoyment: 10/10

Enjoyed it, loved it, will be one of my favourite romance animes. The thought-provoking story, the vibrantly coloured art, beautiful songs and intriguing characters, all of them play a part in the enjoyment.


Overall: 9/10

School ends, you and your friends take different paths. And one day, probably a few years or even many years later, you look back at the school days and wish for another event like that again.

It’s no secret that many slice of life or rom-com's are often pigeonholed and derided in the anime committee for never going anywhere, bereft from subsistence and having an oversaturation of them. As someone who is a fan of this genre and has seen a fair share of romantic comedies (rom-coms), SNAFU is certainly a standout. For a summary of this review, scroll to the last two paragraphs.
[Setting]
While the setting to most slice of life shows typically aren't anything more than just a backdrop for the characters, I feel that there was a bit more nuance and thought that went into SNAFU’s. High School Clubsare often just plot points to unite your main characters who wouldn’t normally talk to each other or socially interact in normal circumstances. However, the use of clubs here, while itself a cliche, is used a little different context wise. In SNAFU, it serves to highlight the positive attributes of characters who would normally be considered unlikeable. It also serves to help others help themselves, something far more useful long term than just helping them. That in itself matches with the less idealistic and more practical viewpoints of characters like Yukino and Hachiman, which I thought was clever.


[Writing]

The writing is both strong and falls short in a few areas. Its greatest strength lies in its way to handle very pessimistic social commentary on interactions between high school students that can feel both relatable and true. Many situations that are written seem considerably more realistic to what happens in high schools than other conventional high school rom-coms. This also makes for some good comedy that incorporates Hachiman's unique perspective. Both the social commentary and comedy is told in a straightforward manner and there are plenty of times where the dialogue gets profound.


As good as the comedic and dramatic writing is, it falls flat when it diverts to romance occasionally. While the title of the anime (My Youth Romantic Comedy is Wrong as I Expected) itself does admit this, the romance aspect in this first season is honestly lacking. I understand the intention was to create a less typical romance anime, but scenes with romance are too sparse to hold any real weight in the grand scheme of things. Additionally, said romantic scenes are usually interrupted by some typical plot device or event (like a phone call). It feels a little out of place when SNAFU is clearly separating itself from the typical shows in its genre by clumsily using conventional and cheap ways to withhold romantic development. 


[Characters]

When it comes to the characters themselves, the leads are handled very well, particularly Hachiman. Not only is his own very twisted, negative view vastly different from the homogenous crop of stereotypical romance protagonists the genre is accustomed to, but he, later on, will show in a unique way that he isn’t as selfish and self-minded as he appears to be. Additionally, when he does display traits in line with your average male lead in a rom-com, like his density regarding obvious signs of females being attracted to him, it makes sense when you learn about his personal life experiences. He is refreshing, well-developed and plays up the anti-hero role quite well. 


The other two leads, Yuigahama and Yukinoshita, also help bring some balance to the otherwise pessimistic and facetious tone of the anime. Yui helps achieve this while also being a great character foil for Hachiman. She is more or less the bubbly, kind hearted member of the club and as such, brings some needed (even if misplaced) optimism and charisma. Yui also has her own social issues, being blindingly obedient and submissive to popular classmates whims. Her social shortcomings to the club make for a believable and clever way to bring the three together. Yukino also adds really nicely to the dynamic of the three, by being very similar and dissimilar to our protagonist. She too is rather intelligent, can seem cold hearted and ruthless, and is ostracized by her classmates. Unlike Hachiman though, she is very kind deep down and is being alienated for her beauty and allure; And despite her and Hachiman being loners, they clearly have vastly different viewpoints, which makes for some intriguing situations later on. 


While the main three characters are very well written and developed, unfortunately, I feel like the side characters were far too neglected and relegated to comedy roles. Characters like Yoshiteru and Totsuka were likeable enough, but had little development and could have sufficiently added to SNAFU's themes by revealing the underlying negative feelings of both characters that are associated with their stereotypes. 


[Soundtrack/Audio]

The music, for the most part, is good, though I wouldn’t say it’s magnificent. It sufficiently matches and even at times adds to the mood of the scene as background music is supposed to do, but it doesn’t necessarily have many tracks that stand out and help breathe life into a scene. The voice acting (at least for the sub) is very well done, as each voice actor gives an excellent performance and creates a strong association from character design to voice.


[Art/Animation]

The art style and animation are good overall, though personally, I thought that the eyes of Yukino and Yui at times felt a little too close together or awkwardly placed. I will give praise to Hachiman's character design, as it perfectly fits him and is drawn in much less detail than his classmates. He has a distinctive feel compared to everyone else and this helps him stand out all the more. There is some nice art direction touches in this season, like having both Yukino and Hachiman at opposite sides of the table, serving as a metaphor for their opposing viewpoints and having Yui in the middle trying to bring some balance to the two.


[Summary/TL;DR]

SNAFU is an overall great rom-com/slice of life/drama anime that is akin to a breath of fresh air compared to many animes in its genre. Easily the biggest draw to the show is the main character Hachiman, who is very different from a typical protagonist in this genre with his loner demeanor and nihilistic attitude. The other two female leads are equally well done, providing extra depth to SNAFU's characterization. The writing is another draw, as it often depicts and makes commentary on social interactions in high school told by Hachiman; Doing so uses his own character bias to full effect. It also develops and changes from a comedy to a character focused drama as the show progresses. It is a little unsatisfying in the romance department, as though they attempted to handle romance in a different way, there were too few romantic scenes and those were dampened by incorporating phone interruptions or other similar tropes to halt romantic development between characters. 


The setting, while nothing especially unique, is a considerably more realistic depiction of high schools. The use of the club helps bring out the relatable and kinder elements of the main cast without betraying their characters entirely. The art is decent and the soundtrack, while mostly forgettable, utilizes softer songs rather well and has a solid OP and ED. Those looking for a rom-com that goes against the grain and provides great characters, some profound dialogue, and unique writing would likely enjoy this. Score: 7/10.

I love this show!
If it's anything about this show that stands out from the rest, it's its cast. They just have so much depth and so much thought poured into them. They aren't just one dimensional unlike many other slice of life shows.
Though, I don't necessarily like them because they're intelligent and philosophical characters, but I like them because they are flawed. They carry actual weight and their behaviors are understandable and sympathetic. Despite carrying the classic tropes of a harem anime, they are well deconstructed—almost to the point that one can begin to wonder if it's a harem anime in the first place.
The charactersin this anime are open up for different interpretations. The show itself has an intellectual edge that many can appreciate. You may find yourself agreeing with one side of the argument over the other, but others who watch the same show may not be so inclined to agree.


Speaking of which, the chemistry between characters here is what really sells the show.


I for one find the main character, Hachiman Hikigaya, to be unique in his own right. I have never seen a protagonist like him before. Everything is written in his point-of-view so he's much more sympathetic than he normally should be. And no, he isn't the overly skilled, overly cool, and overly glorified main male lead that get's all the girls for shallow reasons that we're so used to getting in more recent anime of the same genre. His background isn't just some lip service to justify his analytical skills and attitude. We can genuinely find his monologues to be amusing, so he isn't anything like the too obvious wish fulfillment protagonist that we frequently get.


The supporting characters are no less than interesting themselves. Despite them playing the roles in what you'd normally find on a harem genre, they aren't one dimensional. Many of them don't just suck up to Hachiman immediately and they all have interesting qualities that will keep you entertained with them.


If I were to talk about the show's finer points, I might as well be writing for the whole page. My recommendation? Watch it.
